Historically, the first natural xanthone described was gentisin (1,7-dihydroxy-3-methoxyxanthone) in 1821, isolated from the plant Gentiana lutea [ 5] and the first prenylxanthone derivative, tajixanthone, was isolated from the mycelium of Aspergillus stellatus in 1970 [ 6]. However, the first synthesis proposed for a xanthone (hydroxyxanthone) was achieved by Michael, in 1883, and later by Kostanecki and Nessler, in 1891, through the distillation of O-hydroxy-benzoic acid, acetic anhydride and a phenol [ 7, 8], or by heating phenyl salicylate alone [ 4, 9] ( Scheme 2), while the first total synthesis of a naturally occurring xanthone was described by Ullmann and Panchaud, in 1906, for euxanthone [ 10].
